newsitem.title: JAPAN: General Sekiyu to export Okinawa refinery naphtha.
newsitem.headline: General Sekiyu to export Okinawa refinery naphtha.

text.p: General Sekiyu KK said on Wednesday it would start exporting to Asian countries its share of naphtha produced at a refinery in southern Japan, instead of selling the supplies in the domestic market.
General Sekiyu has an 87.5 percent stake in the 100,000 barrel-per-day Nansei Sekiyu refinery on Japan's southernmost island of Okinawa.
Okinawa is closer to South Korea, Taiwan and some of China's coastal cities than it is to most major cities in Japan.
"The cheaper freight is behind the decision," a General Sekiyu spokesman said.
Trading house Sumitomo Corp has the remaining 12.5 percent interest in the Nansei Sekiyu plant.
General Sekiyu has already started selling naphtha from the Okinawa refinery to a few Asian firms including China's Shanghai Gas Co, the spokesman said.
The refiner, which exported only a small quantity of naphtha last year, plans to export its total share of Nansei Sekiyu's naphtha output, or 100,000 kilolitres, this year, he said.
Oil industry analysts said it would be the first time for a Japanese refiner to export naphtha on a regular basis.
Japanese refiners have third-party processing contracts with Asian countries, but have not exported naphtha under term contracts before, an industry source said.
Sumitomo Corp said it would continue selling its share of refined products in the domestic market.
General Sekiyu is owned 49 percent by Exxon Corp.
